abstract: With food aid to Somalia blocked by Islamist militants, aids groups are using vouchers to help some refugees get food to survive.
snippet: With food aid to Somalia blocked by Islamist militants, aids groups are using vouchers to help some refugees get food to survive.
lead_paragraph: The town of Dhobley, Somalia, sits at the gateway of hell.  Just west of Dhobley is the border with Kenya, and the road to Dadaab, which hosts a giant complex of refugee camps; Dhobley has become the last stop in Somalia for a growing stream of desperate, starving people in flight from famine.  In Dhobley, as well, drought has ruined crops and felled cows.   There is no government to help.  The town is a battleground; control of Dhobley has teetered between the Shabaab Islamist militant group and government forces.  Shabaab has blocked food aid from entering Dhobley and burned a food truck, but soldiers from all sides have stolen food meant for the destitute.   The usual street life of an African village - children playing, women laughing together - has vanished.   Gunshots are a constant background noise - "like birds singing," said Tracy Stover, the emergency coordinator in Dadaab for the humanitarian group World Concern.

headline.main: In Famine, Vouchers Can Be Tickets to Survival
